title.narrative: Enhanced shelter intervention by upgrading 100 residential Sub-Standard Buildings, repairing 150 non-residential buildings, improving the sites of 10 Informal Settlements and providing 100 tailored shelter assistance to improve access and circulation for 390 children at risk and 260 older persons at risk in Baalbek-Hermel and Bekaa governorates.

description.narrative: This project will target and provide direct shelter assistance to 390 children at risk (children parents, children spouses, children carers, children with special educational needs) and 260 older persons at risk (single older persons, older persons with children, older persons unable to care for selves) –including with mobility limitations –living in Sub-Standard residential Buildings (SSBs), non-residential buildings and Informal Settlements (IS). The beneficiaries are displaced Syrians (85% of the total for interventions in SSBs and 100% in ISs) and vulnerable Lebanese (15% of the total for the interventions in SSBs) living in Baalbek-Hermel and Bekaa Governorates.The shelter assistance delivered by Medair will include: 100 rehabilitation of residential SSBs150minor repair (MR) of non-residential buildings located outside the ISs 100 tailored shelter assistance for children and elderly with mobility limitations to improve their accessibility and circulation within SSBs and ISs (including distribution of household items like commode chairs if appropriate) 350 fire mitigation in residential and non-residential SSBs 10 site improvement of Informal Settlements (ISs). All shelter interventions in SSBs will provide access to functioning WASH facilities (if appropriate) this includes, but it is not limited to, connecting to piping/water network, rehabilitation of toilets and kitchens and installation of water storage tanks. Medair also proposes to secure tenancy for beneficiaries through collaboration and agreements with landlords, thereby improving secured andlonger-term access to the improved quality housing. Whenever possible, secured tenancy will involve an agreed rent-free or rent-reduced period for the supported household (HH). To complement this, Medair will also include tailored shelter interventions for children and older persons with mobility limitations in its SSB rehabilitation and minor repair works, where appropriate. All works will be undertaken by a contractor under the supervision of Medair team and in line with technical sector standards to ensure quality. The tailored shelter assistance for children and older persons with limited mobility will be designed following the recommendation criteria detailed in the “Design Standards and Specifications” in Medair’s PwSN SOP and in consultation with the persons concerned and their caregiver. The intervention in residential and non-residential SSBs will also include a comprehensive fire programme with fire awareness sessions, the distribution of fire extinguishers and the installation of smoke/CO2 detectors in all the targeted SSBs. Medair will conduct site improvements in targeted ISs in the Bekaa Valley through the community approach and using cash transfer modality. Priority will be given to the settlements with the largest number of children and elderly at risk, in particular with mobility problems. Interventions may include, but will not be limited to, improve access to latrines and shelters for children and older persons at risk by graveling and to protect physically children and older persons at risk by draining channels. Medair will encourage the community to consider PwSN friendly recreational spaces in the design of all site level interventions. Potential cases for these shelter interventions will be identified and selected for assessment throughthe following methods: Unified Assessment RAIS database RIMS database Internal referrals from other sector teams including Health and Shelter External referrals from other actors (protection, basic assistance, WASH)Coordination with Protection and Shelter Working Groups Medair will adopt a Case Management Approach to ensure needs outside of Shelter and WASH that are effectively identified and referred to other service providers.
